articles.headline: Senate Health Bill in Peril as C.B.O. Predicts 22 Million More Uninsured
articles.snippet: The figure released by the Congressional Budget Office is only slightly lower than the 23 million more uninsured under the House version of the legislation.
articles.abstract: The figure released by the Congressional Budget Office is only slightly lower than the 23 million more uninsured under the House version of the legislation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act was edging toward collapse on Monday after the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said it would increase the number of people without health insurance by 22 million by 2026.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Shareholders Demand More Drastic Shifts at Nestlé
articles.snippet: The changes requested by the Third Point hedge fund underscore the idea that legacy food brands must radically shake up their portfolios to remain profitable.
articles.abstract: The changes requested by the Third Point hedge fund underscore the idea that legacy food brands must radically shake up their portfolios to remain profitable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nestlé, the Swiss food giant that helps bring the world Stouffer’s frozen dinners, Kit Kat candy bars and even L’Oréal hair coloring, is feeling pressure to change its corporate recipe.

articles.headline: With Crowding in U.S. Market, Activist Investors Look to Europe
articles.snippet: American hedge funds are taking their aggressive strategies overseas and finding more acceptance from international shareholders.
articles.abstract: American hedge funds are taking their aggressive strategies overseas and finding more acceptance from international shareholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Activist investors — money managers who seek to shake up a company’s strategy in search of huge paydays — have been growing in size and power in the United States, bending the knees of even the biggest corporate titans.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Can Good Corporate Citizenship Be Measured?
articles.snippet: Investors have embraced a new three-letter abbreviation — E.S.G., or “environmental, social and governance” — as a yardstick for companies. How meaningful is it?
articles.abstract: Investors have embraced a new three-letter abbreviation — E.S.G., or “environmental, social and governance” — as a yardstick for companies. How meaningful is it?
articles.lead_paragraph: If you spend time around corporate boardrooms these days, you’ll hear the abbreviation “E.S.G.” thrown around with such frequency it is almost a trope.

articles.headline: Canada’s Secret to Resisting the West’s Populist Wave
articles.snippet: Minority voters have a large political voice, immigration is seen as positive and multicultural identities are encouraged.
articles.abstract: Minority voters have a large political voice, immigration is seen as positive and multicultural identities are encouraged.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO — As right-wing populism has roiled elections and upended politics across the West, there is one country where populists have largely failed to break through: Canada.

articles.headline: With 3 Words, Supreme Court Opens a World of Uncertainty for Refugees
articles.snippet: The “bona fide relationship” standard in the Supreme Court’s travel ban decision could shut out thousands of refugees who lack family ties in the United States.
articles.abstract: The “bona fide relationship” standard in the Supreme Court’s travel ban decision could shut out thousands of refugees who lack family ties in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Fouad Dagoum fled Sudan after his village was ransacked by militia members who captured, detained and tortured him until his body was limp.

articles.headline: How Silicon Valley Pushed Coding Into American Classrooms
articles.snippet: Code.org, a tech-backed nonprofit, is pressing schools to teach computer science. But are tech firms swaying education to serve their own interests?
articles.abstract: Code.org, a tech-backed nonprofit, is pressing schools to teach computer science. But are tech firms swaying education to serve their own interests?
articles.lead_paragraph: At a White House gathering of tech titans last week, Timothy D. Cook, the chief executive of Apple, delivered a blunt message to President Trump on how public schools could better serve the nation’s needs. To help solve a “huge deficit in the skills that we need today,” Mr. Cook said, the government should do its part to make sure students learn computer programming.

articles.headline: Google Fined Record $2.7 Billion in E.U. Antitrust Ruling
articles.snippet: The search giant must change how it provides some of its services to comply with the competition decision in Europe.
articles.abstract: The search giant must change how it provides some of its services to comply with the competition decision in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google suffered a major blow on Tuesday after European antitrust officials fined the search giant a record $2.7 billion for unfairly favoring some of its own services over those of rivals.

articles.headline: Vote Delayed as G.O.P. Struggles to Marshal Support for Health Care Bill
articles.snippet: The retreat by Republican leaders dealt another setback to their efforts to dismantle the Affordable Care Act and set up a long summer of health care battles.
articles.abstract: The retreat by Republican leaders dealt another setback to their efforts to dismantle the Affordable Care Act and set up a long summer of health care battles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing intransigent Republican opposition, the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, on Tuesday delayed a vote on legislation to repeal the Affordable Care Act, dealing another setback to Republicans’ seven-year effort to dismantle the health law and setting up a long, heated summer of health care battles.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Robert Pear

articles.headline: When Cutting Access to Health Care, There’s a Price to Pay
articles.snippet: In measure after measure of well-being in rich nations, Americans are among the worst off, with costs to the economy and to individuals.
articles.abstract: In measure after measure of well-being in rich nations, Americans are among the worst off, with costs to the economy and to individuals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senators, the United States is a sick country.

articles.headline: Cyberattack Hits Ukraine Then Spreads Internationally
articles.snippet: This ransomware attack, a more sophisticated assault based on a vulnerability exploited in May, hit companies across the globe.
articles.abstract: This ransomware attack, a more sophisticated assault based on a vulnerability exploited in May, hit companies across the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Computer systems from Ukraine to the United States were struck on Tuesday in an international cyberattack that was similar to a recent assault that crippled tens of thousands of machines worldwide.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth, Mark Scott and Sheera Frenkel
